page.title: 14GROVE PRIORY
page.content: Grove priory is an archeological site near Leighton Buzzard. It was discovered in 1930 and todays archeologists started work in 1972, but on 20th August 1985 it is due to be turned into a sand quarry. The earliest archeological remains found at Grove Priory were from a small Saxon Settlement. Small pits were first discovered and then holes called Post Holes. There have also been monastic finds dated around 1254. Everything on the site is kept clean and tidy. Trowels are used to remove the soil in layers and trowelling is done systematically so that all the ground is covered. Patches of coloured soil can tell the archeologists what had been there in previous years. The finds of the digs are stored in plastic seed trays before being sent to Bedfrod Museum to be catalogued.
